Graphical abstract The mesostructured Cu/AlCeO with different weight ratio of Al2O3 and CeO2 have been prepared for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The Cu/AlCeO showed the high exposed Cu surface area and then improved activity of CO2 conversion. The CeO2 in Cu/AlCeO catalysts can endow the catalysts with strong surface basicity, increase the Cu-CeO2 interface and optimize the surface copper species, which improve the selectivity to methanol. The catalyst Cu/AlCeO-7 with optimized microstructure and surface properties exhibited the much improved activity and selectivity for the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Mesostructured catalysts with optimized microstructure and surface properties endowed them attractive catalytic performance. Herein, the mesostructured AlCeO supports with different weight ratio of Al2O3 and CeO2 have been prepared on the basis of a self-assembly sol-gel process, then 15 wt.% Cu was loaded onto the mesostructured AlCeO supports by incipient wetness impregnation method. The mesostructured AlCeO supports with varied ratio of Al2O3 to CeO2 resulted in the very different Cu particle size, and for the optimized catalyst Cu/AlCeO-7 (the amount of Al2O3 in AlCeO support was 70 wt.%), the Cu crystal size was around 7 nm based on the characterization of XRD and TEM. The Cu/AlCeO-7 catalyst had strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) and more Cu-ceria interface, which was confirmed by the XPS. Furthermore, the Cu/AlCeO-7 catalyst showed the highest exposed Cu surface area (S Cu) (25.5 m2/gcat) from the analysis results of H2-TPR and dissociative chemisorption of nitrous oxide. The CO2-TPD results demonstrated the Cu/AlCeO-7 had strong surface basicity. Hence, Cu/AlCeO-7 catalyst showed the highest space time yield of methanol (STYMeOH). The CO2 conversion (Cu/AlCeO-7, V(H2)/V(CO2) = 3/1, GHSV = 6000 mL h−1 g−1 and P = 4 MPa) was up to 22.5% at 553 K, the methanol selectivity can reach 94% at 473 K, and the STYMeOH was up to 7.2 mmol gcat. -1 h-1 at 493 K. The as-prepared mesostructured Cu/AlCeO-7 exhibited a promising catalyst candidate for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Keywords Cu/AlCeO Mesoporous CO2 hydrogenation Methanol Surface basicity Cu-ceria Interface 1 Introduction CO2 is an attractive and renewable C1 source, and annually, large amount of CO2 is discharged into the atmosphere, which has already caused not only many serious environmental and ecology problems but also the waste of resources [1,2]. In recent years, the reuse of CO2 has attracted great interest and some important progresses have been already made. Up to now, the CO2 has been successfully converted into fuels and chemical raw materials, such as alkanes [3], formic acid [4] and methanol [5]. Methanol is an important chemical commodity that is transported and used worldwide, thus the conversion of CO2 into methanol is a very promising way to solve the problems of CO2 emission and energy shortage [6]. In industry, Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts are employed predominantly [5]. However, the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst still confronted low CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity. In recent years, many new catalysts have been developed. For example, the optimum catalyst composition of Cu-Zn-Zr (the corresponding molar ratio is 38.2:28.6:33.2) prepared by a reverse co-precipitation method showed a high methanol productivity of 219.7 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1 at 2 MPa and 240℃ [1]. The methanol productivity over the catalyst Cu/Zn/Al/Zr with atomic ratio of Zr4+ : (Al3++Zr4+) = 0.3 could be up to 0.16 g mL−1 h−1 at 5 MPa and 543 K [7]. It can be concluded that the Cu-based catalysts show high potential for the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Due to the high surface area and thermal stability, Al2O3 is widely used as support in catalytic industry [8]. In addition, the mesoporous materials possess attractive properties for the practical catalysis, such as high surface area, high thermal stability, adjustable mesostructures, controllable morphologies and tunable pore sizes [9,10]. Recently, we have found that the mesostructured Cu/Al2O3 catalysts have high exposed Cu surface area and show higher performance of the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol compared with the nonporous counterparts. Furthermore, the load amount of Cu on the Al2O3 have been optimized and the value is 15% (See the Supplementary Material). However, the CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity on mesostructured Cu/Al2O3 still need to improve, compared with other catalysts listed in Table 1 . According to previous reports, the carbon-containing intermediates adsorbed on the strong basic site preferred to hydrogenate further to form methanol rather than dissociate to form CO, which demonstrated that the basic surface was beneficial to improve methanol selectivity [7]. The CO2-TPD for CeO2 and ZnO indicated that the CeO2 had the stronger basic sites than that of ZnO [19]. In addition, the ratio of Cu°/Cu+ in Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 prepared by precipitation-reduction method with NaBH4 has the important influence on the performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [17], and the Cu+ species can be generated due to the interaction between copper and ceria [20]. Meanwhile, the experimental and theoretical results demonstrated that the Cu-CeO2 interface was highly active and favorable to the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [12]. More importantly, the existence of strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) between Cu and CeO2 was confirmed and influenced the catalytic performances by electronic modification and/or geometric of the metal particles by oxides [20,21]. Hence, the CeO2 should be a promising promoter and support for Cu based catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Herein, in order to obtain the catalysts with high performance for the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, the mesostructured AlCeO supports with different weight ratio of Al2O3 and CeO2 were synthesized. After 15 wt.% Cu loading, the catalysts were used for the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Aluminium i-propoxide (AR) was purchased from Aladdin (Shanghai, China). Glucose (AR), HNO3 (AR), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (AR) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (AR) were from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Distilled water was used in the experiments. All chemicals in the catalysts preparation were used as received without further purification. The quartz sands (60–80 meshes, 99.9%) were form Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Tianjin, China), and they were calcined at 873 K for 4 h in muffle furnace before test. The gases in the characterization and reaction were purchased from Huaerwen industrial Co. Ltd. (Wuhan, China), and the purity was 99.999%. 2.2 Preparation of mesoporous Cu/AlCeO catalysts The mesoporous composites of Al2O3/CeO2 (AlCeO) with different weigh ratio of Al2O3 and CeO2 were prepared by a modified self-assembly sol-gel process as reported for the mesoporous Al2O3 synthesis [22]. In short, the proper amounts of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and aluminium i-propoxide and 14.4 g glucose were dissolved in 216 mL distilled water under vigorous stirring, and the resultant solution was constantly stirred at 308 K for 6 h. The detailed dosage was shown in Table 2 . Then, the diluted nitric acid solution (10 wt.%) was added to the above-mentioned solution until the pH was around 5, and subsequently stirred for 24 h. The solution was put into an oven at 373 K overnight, and then the black solid formed. The black solid was calcined at 873 K for 4 h in muffle furnace to remove the template. Finally, about 5 g of power were obtained, which was marked AlCeO-x (x represented the different Al2O3 weight amount within AlCeO support, and 9 (90 wt.%), 7 (70 wt.%) and 5 (50 wt.%)). Here, the mass of Ce source (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O) and Al source (aluminium i-propoxide) were calculated by the weight of Al2O3 and CeO2. The catalysts with 15 wt.% Cu loading were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. The water as the solvent deteriorated the microstructure of samples under hydrothermal condition [8], then, the certain amount Cu(NO3)2 ethanol solution was added dropwise to AlCeO supports and dried at 353 K. Thereafter, the samples were reduced at 553 K for 2 h in a flow of 20 vol% H2/N2. The reduced samples with 15 wt.% Cu were denoted as Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5. The Cu/Al2O3 with 15 wt.% Cu was also prepared by the same method as the reference. In addition, the samples calcined at 553 K for 2 h in air were denoted as CuO/Al2O3, CuO/AlCeO-9, CuO/AlCeO-7 and CuO/AlCeO-5. 2.3 Characterization Before the characterization, the samples were pelletized, crushed and sieved to 40–60 meshes. The N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were carried out at 77.3 K on the TristarⅡ3020 autosorption analyzer (Micromeritics Instrument Corporation, USA). The samples were first outgassed in flowing N2 at 423 K for 6 h. The surface areas were calculated from the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, the pore size distributions were obtained by the desorption branches using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, and the total pore volumes were evaluated from the amount of N2 adsorbed at a relative pressure 0.99. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were recorded on the field emission scanning electron microscope (Hitachi S4800, Japan) with accelerating voltage of 1 kV. And the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were collected on a JEOL electron microscope (JEM-2010 F, Japan) with accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The chemical compositions of catalysts were measured by the X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF). XPS measurements were performed on an AXIS-ULTRA DLD-600 W spectrometer (Shimadzu, Japan) using Al Kα radiation as the excitation source (hν = 1486.6 eV, intrinsic line width was 0.3 eV). The pressure of the analysis chamber was kept 10−8 - 10-9 Torr during the experiments. Before the narrow scanning, the sample was firstly checked by the survey spectra with a pass energy of 160 eV. The spectra of Cu 2p and Ce 3d were recorded with a pass energy of 40 eV and all the binding energy values were calibrated using the C 1 s peak at 284.5 eV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were measured in ambient atmosphere, and used the X-ray diffractometer (PANalytical Empyrean, Holland) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5408 Å) at 30 mA and 40 kV. The diffraction was measured from 10° to 80° at a rate of 10°/min. The average size of Cu crystal was calculated based on the Scherrer equation from the most intense Cu peak at 2θ of 43.3° as shown below: (1) d = 0.89 λ B cos θ where d was the average crystallite diameter, λ was the X-ray wave length (1.54 Å), and B was the full width of half maximum (FWHM) of the Cu diffraction peak, which was the main experimental error in the determination of particle size. N2O chemisorption and H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were measured on chemisorption analyzer (VDSorb-91 X, China). In the test of N2O chemisorption, the samples (50 mg) were reduced in the mixed gas (5 vol.% H2/Ar) at 553 K for 2 h, and then switched to He flow until the temperature dropped to 333 K. Then, the samples were exposed to 5 vol.% N2O/He at 333 K for 1 h to ensure that the metallic copper was completely oxidized to Cu+. When the catalysts cooled down to room temperature with He flow, the catalysts were reduced again in 5 vol.% H2/Ar mixture with a temperature programmed reduction up to 873 K, and the moles of consumed H2 was denoted as n1. The exposed Cu surface area (S Cu) and copper dispersion (D Cu) were evaluated from the consumption of H2 as following [17,23]: (2) S Cu =(2 n1 × Na)/(N × m) (m2/gcat) (3) D Cu (%) = 100 × 2 n1/n where Na was the Avogadro’s constant (6.022 × 1023 mol−1), N (1.47 × 1019) was the number of metallic Cu atoms per square meter, m was the amount of catalyst and n was the moles of Cu atoms in the samples calculated by the results of XRF. The experimental error in S Cu and D Cu was estimated ±1% from three repeat steady-state measurements. In the test of H2-TPR, 50 mg of the dried sample was put in 5 vol.% H2/Ar at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. The temperature was raised from 323 to 873 K at a heating rate of 10 K/min. Temperature programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) were carried out on a chemisorption analyzer (VDSorb-91 X, China). Before the test, the standard sample (CuO powder) was used to check the instrument, and the experimental error was < 4%. All the dried samples were reduced at 553 K for 1 h with feed gas (5 vol.% H2/Ar). After cooling to room temperature, the catalysts were saturated in CO2 at a flow rate of 30 mL/min at 313 K for 1 h, and then the physical adsorbed molecules were removed by the flowing He. The processes of desorption were performed at a heating rate of 10 K/min under He flow up to 773 K. 2.4 Catalytic tests The hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol was performed in a fixed-bed reactor (the diameter of reaction tube was 6 mm). Prior to the test, the samples were pelletized, crushed and sieved to 40–60 meshes. Then, the catalyst (0.4 g) was diluted by 0.8 mL inert quartz sands and packed into the vertical fixed-bed reactor (the aspect ratio was about 5). The inert quartz sands were loaded in both sides of the catalyst bed. Thereafter, the catalysts were reduced in an atmosphere of 20 vol% H2/N2 with a 100 mL/min flow under atmospheric pressure at 553 K for 2 h. Then, the pressure in fixed-bed reactor slowly was risen to 4.0 MPa. The catalytic activity was measured at 473–553 K, 4.0 MPa and GHSV = 6000 mL h−1 g−1. The mixture gas (V(H2)/V(CO2)/V(N2) = 9/3/1, volume ratio) was fed through the reactor with 40 mL/min flow rate. Online analysis of the products was determined by an SP-6890 gas chromatograph (Lu’nan, China), thereinto the gas products were detected with TDX-01 column and a TCD detector, meanwhile, the liquid products were detected by SE-54 column and an FID detector. And all data were recorded after 2 h time-on-stream. The activity and selectivity were calculated by internal standard from an average of three repeat steady-state measurements at each temperature. The methanol amount was tested by the standard curve of methanol amount and peak area. At first, the different amount of methanol was tested used the SE-54 column and an FID detector, and then the corresponding peak areas could be obtained. At last, the methanol amount would be obtained according to the peak area detected by the on-line gas chromatography. The experimental error in conversion and selectivity were within ±3% and ±2%, respectively. The CO2 conversion (X, C-mol%), carbon-based selectivity (S, C-mol%), yield (Y) and space-time yield (STY, mmol g-1 h-1) of methanol and CO were calculated by the following equations: (4) X = m o l e s C O 2 ( i n ) m o l e s N 2 ( i n ) − m o l e s C O 2 ( O u t ) m o l e s N 2 ( o u t ) m o l e s C O 2 ( i n ) m o l e s N 2 ( i n ) × 100 % (5) S M e O H = m o l e s M e O H m o l e s M e O H + m o l e s C O × 100 % (6) S C O = m o l e s C O m o l e s M e O H + m o l e s C O × 100 % (7) Y = X × S (8) S T Y C O = Y C O × m o l e s C O 2 ( i n ) W c a t . × t × 100 % (9) S T Y M e O H = Y M e O H × m o l e s C O 2 ( i n ) W c a t . × t × 100 % (10) T O F M e O H = S T Y M e O H × N a S C u × N × 3600 × 1000 where Wcat. was the total amount of catalyst (g), t was the reaction time (h), Na was the Avogadro’s constant (6.022 × 1023 mol−1), N (1.47 × 1019) was the number of metallic Cu atoms per square meter. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural and structural properties of supports The mesostructure of the as-prepared AlCeO supports was characterized by N2 sorption and the results were shown in Fig. 1 . All the sorption isotherms were type IV and showed obvious N2 adsorption leap at the relative pressure range of 0.5-0.8, which was characteristic of typical mesoporous structure. For the Al2O3, AlCeO-9, AlCeO-7 and AlCeO-5, the corresponding BET surface areas were 337, 310, 298 and 223 m2/g and the pore volume were 0.56, 0.55, 0.46 and 0.35 cm3/g, respectively. The pore size distribution of the Al2O3, AlCeO-9, AlCeO-7 and AlCeO-5 all centered around 5.0 nm (Fig. 1B). With the increase of CeO2 adding amount, the BET surface area decreased due to gradually deteriorated mesostructure of corresponding sample. Nevertheless, all the samples showed the obvious mesostructure and narrow mesopore size distribution, and it can be confirmed by the SEM images, which were displayed in Fig. 2 and exhibited loose spongy porous structure in all the samples. XRD was used to understand the crystalline of as-prepared mesostructued samples and the corresponding results were showed in Fig. 3 . In Fig. 3A, the diffraction peaks of the Al2O3, AlCeO-9 and AlCeO-7 near 37.2°, 45.8° and 66.7° could be assigned to the gamma Al2O3 (JCPDS 01-1301), and the peaks of the AlCeO-7 and AlCeO-5 around 28.3°, 32.8°, 47.2° and 56.2° could be assigned to CeO2 (JCPDS 08-0800). Notably, the diffraction peaks of Al2O3 in the AlCeO-5 and the CeO2 in AlCeO-9 can not been well identified, which may be the overall reflection of the combined effects, such as low crystalline and decreased Al2O3 or CeO2 contents in corresponding samples. 3.2 Textural and structural properties of the catalysts After the loading of 15 wt.% Cu, the catalysts Cu/Al2O3, Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5 (reduced by 20 vol% H2/N2 at 553 K) were also checked by XRD (Fig. 3B). The diffraction peaks of Al2O3 and CeO2 were similar with those in Fig. 3A, which demonstrated the phases of supports were not changed after the metallic copper loading. In addition, the diffraction peaks around 43.3°, 50.4° and 74.1° for all patterns could be well indexed as the (111), (200) and (220) planes of the copper (JCPDS 04-0836), respectively. Notably, the copper diffraction peak intensity of these catalysts was different. The copper diffraction peaks on Cu/Al2O3 showed much sharper peaks than those on other Ce-contained catalysts, which implied the largest crystalline size in all the samples. The intensity of copper diffraction peaks in Cu/AlCeO-7 were weaker than those of Cu/AlCeO-9 and Cu/AlCeO-5, especially the peaks around 50.4° and 74.1°. While the intensity of copper diffraction peaks in Cu/AlCeO-9 was stronger than that of Cu/AlCeO-5. The average crystal size of copper for Cu/Al2O3, Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5 was calculated to be 19, 12, 7 and 10 nm, respectively, according to the Scherrer equation applied to the Cu peak at 2θ of 43.3°. According to the reported literatures, the SMSI could promote the dispersion of supported copper [24–26]. And the SMSI exited between Cu and CeO2 [20,21]. Hence, the CeO2 added into supports can promote the Cu dispersion. However, the average crystal size of copper in Cu/AlCeO-5 increased compared to Cu/AlCeO-7, which was attributed to the low BET surface area in AlCeO-5 [27]. Thus, the deteriorated mesostructure would lead to the increase of the copper average crystal size. Finally, the Cu/AlCeO-7 had the smallest copper crystalline size. TEM was used to direct observe the microstructure and crystalline of the as-prepared catalysts Cu/Al2O3, Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5 reduced at 553 K and the images were showed in Fig. 4 . According to high resolution images (insets in Fig. 4), the well dispersed dark particles were Cu or CeO2 nanoparticles, the lattice fringes with a d-spacing of 0.21 nm could be assigned to be (111) planes of metallic Cu. The lattice fringe with a d-spacing of 0.31 nm could be assigned to be the (111) planes of CeO2 in the catalyst Cu/AlCeO-9 (inset, Fig. 4B), Cu/AlCeO-7 (inset, Fig. 4C) and Cu/AlCeO-5 (inset, Fig. 4D). The size of Cu particles for Cu/Al2O3, Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5 obtained from the projected areas was estimated, and Cu particle size distribution was shown in insets of Fig. 4. It was seen that the average size of Cu particles in Cu/Al2O3 (Fig.4A) was about 19 nm and larger than those in other catalysts, and the CeO2 added into the catalysts inhibited the growth of Cu particles. The Cu/AlCeO-7 had the smallest Cu size and the result was consistent with the result of XRD, implied that the appropriate weight ratio of Al2O3/CeO2 can result in the optimized Cu dispersion. After the loading of Cu, the catalysts reduced at 553 K have been also characterized by N2 sorption and the corresponding sorption isotherms and pore size distribution were showed in Fig. 5 . The isotherms for all catalysts were the typical type IV and had the obvious N2 adsorption leap at the relative pressure range of 0.5-0.8, which were basically the similar with those of the supports (Fig.1) and indicated that the mesostructure of the catalysts was well maintained after the Cu loading. Notably, the isotherm for Cu/AlCeO-5 was very different from other three samples and the smaller N2 adsorption amount and wide leap clearly demonstrated its deteriorated mesostructure. The detailed data was shown in Table 3 . 3.3 Surface chemical properties of catalysts The Cu loading amount in catalysts reduced at 553 K was confirmed by XRF, which were shown in Table 3 and close to the value added (15 wt.%). In addition, the exposed Cu surface area (S Cu) and dispersion (D Cu) were calculated based on the N2O-chemisorption and shown in Table 3. It was found that the appropriate addition of CeO2 into Al2O3 can well promote the S Cu and D Cu, and the Cu/AlCeO-7 had the highest S Cu and D Cu. The S Cu and D Cu of catalysts were seemed to be related to the Cu particles size, and the catalysts with smaller size would have the higher S Cu and D Cu. The metal-support interaction of as-prepared catalysts was characterized by H2-TPR and the results were shown in Fig. 6 . For the CuO/Al2O3, there were two reduction peaks roughly, and they could be deconvoluted into two Gaussian peaks at 513 K (β) and 583 K (γ), which were ascribed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO and "bulk-like" CuO species, respectively [28,29]. The reduction temperature of CeO2 was above 600 K [20], hence, the reduction peaks should be from the reduction of CuO in this work. For CuO/AlCeO-9, CuO/AlCeO-7 and CuO/AlCeO-5 catalysts, the reduction peaks of highly dispersed CuO and "bulk-like" CuO species were shifted to the lower temperature (around 489 and 528 K, respectively). The similar results were observed in Cu/Zn/Al catalysts, and positions of the peaks shift to lower temperatures with the introduction of the CeO2 [30], and the interaction between CuO and support was considered to affect the reduction of CuO by changing the strength of Cu-O bond [31,32]. Hence, the reduction peaks shift to lower temperatures can be attributed to the interaction between the CuO and AlCeO supports. In addition, there was an overlapping reduction peak at 467 K (α peak) in CuO/AlCeO-5, which should be the reduction of dispersed CuO strongly interacted with the ceria surface [33]. The H2 consumed and reducibility of as-prepared catalysts were shown in Table 4 . It was seen that the total H2 consumed and reducibility increased by the increase of the CeO2 adding amount, which was attributed to the increase of highly dispersed copper oxide from Fig. 6 [30]. For CuO/AlCeO-7 at γ peak, the consumed H2 was much less than those of other catalysts, which illustrated that the "bulk-like" CuO species in the CuO/AlCeO-7 were much less than other catalysts, which was in agreement with the results of XRD and TEM. XPS spectra were used to identify the chemical state of Cu and Ce related surface species. Fig. 7 A showed the Cu XPS spectra of CuO/Al2O3, CuO/AlCeO-9, CuO/AlCeO-7 and CuO/AlCeO-5 calcined at 553 K. The Cu 2p3/2 signal can be deconvoluted into three Gaussian peaks. The peaks around 933.2 and 943.0 eV were ascribed to Cu2+ into CuO specie [20,34], and another peak around 937.3 eV related to spinel CuAl2O4 produced by the diffusion of Cu2+ into Al2O3 lattice [35]. Besides, the Cu 2p1/2 spectra were observed around 953.3 eV, which also was ascribed to the Cu2+ into CuO specie. The ratio of Cu2+ from CuAl2O4 and CuO species over these samples could be estimated by the area of corresponding peaks, which was shown in Table 5 . The proportion of the two Cu2+ species was very different due to the different weight ratio of the Al2O3 and CeO2 in the supports, and the proportions of CuAl2O4 and CuO species were 0.69, 0.61, 0.45 and 0.35 in CuO/Al2O3, CuO/AlCeO-9, CuO/AlCeO-7 and CuO/AlCeO-5, respectively, which decreased with the increase of CeO2 addition. The oxidation states of Ce in the samples calcined at 553 K were analyzed based on the curves of Ce 3d spectra obtained from XPS measurements, which were shown in Fig. 7 B. The peaks marked as v (ca. 916.1 eV), v' (ca. 906.4 eV) and v”' (ca. 900.2 eV) were the characteristic of Ce4+ 3d3/2, while the peaks labeled as u (ca. 897.9 eV), u' (ca. 888.3 eV) and u”' (ca. 881.8 eV) resulted from Ce4+ 3d5/2 [34,35]. The results showed that there was only Ce4+ specie on the surface on the samples. In CO2 hydrogenation, there will be a part of Cu° specie was oxidized into Cu+ specie, which was considered to be the active center for CO2 hydrogenation [17]. For the spent catalysts, the Cu° and Cu+ species should coexist on the surface of the catalysts. The Cu 2p3/2 binding energies was difficult to distinguish Cu° and Cu+ species because they are essentially identical, however, they can be distinguished by the Auger electron lines of Cu [34,36]. Fig. 7C showed the in-situ Cu LMM Auger electron spectroscopies of the spent catalysts. It was seen that the peak at 918.6 eV was ascribed to the Cu° specie and the peak around 916.4 eV was attributed to the Cu+ specie. The ratio of Cu+/Cu° on the surface of spent catalysts was shown in Table 5. It was seen that the ratio of Cu+/Cu° over Cu/AlCeO-9 and Cu/AlCeO-7 increased with the CeO2 adding amount, but it decreased over Cu/AlCeO-5, which might be attributed to the less copper-ceria interface. The ratio of Cu+/Cu° in Cu-based catalysts also had been evidenced to influence the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation [17]. Fig. 7D was the in-situ XPS spectra of Ce 3d, and the peaks labeled as v” (903.1 eV) and u” (883.6 eV) appeared in the spent catalysts at 493 K compared with those of calcined catalysts, which were associated with Ce3+ specie (3d104f1 state of Ce3+) [37]. Apparently, there was a part of Ce4+ was reduced into Ce3+ in the reaction. As previous reports, the reduction temperature of the CeO2 was above 600 K [20], and the ceria cations contacted with Cu(111) was found to be easily alternate between Ce4+ and Ce3+ [12], which was explained by the SMSI between copper and ceria [20,21]. Hence, the atom ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ could be shown the amount of copper-ceria interface, and the higher atom ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ meant the more copper-ceria interface, which had highly efficiency for the synthesis of methanol [12]. The atom ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ was shown in Table 5, and the results implied that the Ce3+ dispersion increased with the addition of CeO2. But the Ce3+ dispersion decreased over the Cu/AlCeO-5, which should be synergistic effect of the crystal size of CeO2 (Fig. 3A) and Cu (Fig. 3B). The basic surface of catalysts can enhance the adsorption of CO2 molecules. In the research, the basicity of supports and corresponding catalysts was measured by the CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD), and Fig. 8 A was the results of CO2-TPD over the Al2O3, AlCeO-9, AlCeO-7 and AlCeO-5. It was seen that the CO2 desorption profiles of supports showed a broad peak, which could be deconvoluted into three Gaussian peaks and marked as α, β and γ, attributed to the desorption of CO2 from weak, medium and strong basic sites, respectively. The position of α, β and γ peaks shifted to the higher temperatures with the addition of the CeO2, indicating that the CeO2 enhanced the strength of surface basicity on the supports. The quantity of basic sites on the supports surface can be calculated by integration of each peak and the corresponding data was summarized in Table 6 . It was seen that the quantity of basic sites increased with the increased CeO2 addition, especially, the density of strong basic site calculated based on BET surface area also increased, which was more correlated with the active site for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation than that from weak and medium basic sites [7]. After loading of 15 wt.% Cu, the surface basicity of the catalysts reduced at 553 K were tested by CO2-TPD (Fig. 8B). The CO2 desorption profiles of catalysts were the similar with those in Fig. 8A. From the Table 6, the quantity of basic sites and density of strong basic site obviously decreased due to the loading of Cu, which showed that the CO2 mainly adsorbed on the supports surface and the Cu would occupy a large number of basic sites on the supports. Meanwhile, it was found that the reduction of the basic sites was less on the catalysts with more CeO2 compared to the corresponding supports, and they were 58%, 57%, 51% and 47% on the Cu/Al2O3, Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5, respectively, which showed that the CeO2 in the catalysts could inhibit the more basic sites from occupying by the supported Cu. According to the results of H2-TPR and XPS, the more Cu particles probably penetrated into supports due to the SMSI, leading to the exposure of more basic sites. The bifunctional mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation was currently accepted on the supported Cu catalysts, which was schematically expressed in Scheme 1 . It was seen that the adsorption and dissociation of hydrogen took place over the Cu sites, while the adsorption of CO2 occurred on the supports. The dissociated hydrogen on the Cu surface transported onto the surface of supports sites via spillover and hydrogenated the adsorbed carbon-containing species to form methanol [38]. The results of CO2 adsorption in this work was agreement with the adsorption sites of CO2 in bifunctional mechanism. Hence, the catalysts with more CeO2 had more basic sites, especially the density of strong basic sites, which can promote the activation of CO2 [7]. 3.4 Hydrogenation of CO2 The catalytic performance for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation over the as-prepared catalysts was shown in Fig. 9 . It showed that the CO2 conversion on Cu/Al2O3, Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5 was 6.4%, 7.9%, 8.4% and 7.4% at 473 K, respectively. And the conversion of CO2 on catalysts rapidly increased with reaction temperature. At 553 K, the conversion of CO2 on the catalysts Cu/Al2O3, Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5 reached 16.4%, 20.8%, 22.5% and 18.3%, respectively. The activity of catalysts with CeO2 was higher than that of Cu/Al2O3, indicating that the CeO2 added to the catalysts could promote the activity for the CO2 hydrogenation. For comparison, Cu/AlCeO-7 catalyst was prepared by co-precipitation with same load amount of Cu, but the conversion of CO2 was only 7.1% and 17.9% at 473 K and 553 K, respectively. The S Cu was an important factor for the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol as previous report [38]. Herein, the value of S Cu followed the order Cu/AlCeO-7 > Cu/AlCeO-5 > Cu/AlCeO-9 > Cu/Al2O3, but the activity of Cu/AlCeO-9 was higher than that of Cu/AlCeO-5. In addition, the similar industrial catalyst Cu/ZnAlO (Cu:Zn = 70:30) with 58 wt.% Cu was prepared by co-precipitation method as the reference, and the S Cu was up to 39 m2/gcat [8]. The Cu/ZnAlO was used in the CO2 hydrogenation and the conversion of CO2 was shown in Fig. 9A, which showed that conversion of CO2 on Cu/ZnAlO was lower that of Cu/AlCeO-7. These results suggested that the mesostructured Cu/AlCeO catalysts with high S Cu can promote the activity in CO2 hydrogenation, but the S Cu was not the only factor for the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. It was reported that the ratio of Cu+/Cu° influenced the catalytic performance [17]. In this work, Cu/AlCeO-9 had higher ratio of Cu+/Cu° than that of the Cu/AlCeO-5, and Cu/AlCeO-7 had the highest ratio of Cu+/Cu°, which showed that high ratio of Cu+/Cu° was seemed to promote the activity of catalysts. Methanol was the product of interest for CO2 hydrogenation over the catalysts, while CO and H2O were the mainly byproducts in the research. In addition, a small amount of dimethyl ether formed at high temperature. Fig. 9B showed the selectivity to methanol as a function of reaction temperatures. The selectivity was highly affected by the reaction temperature and the value was the highest at 473 K, and then decreased rapidly with the increased reaction temperature and CO generation increased at the same time. In addition, some methanol dehydrated into dimethyl ether. Notably, the selectivity of methanol was only 59% on the Cu/Al2O3 at 473 K, and the values was up to 78%, 94% and 96% over the Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5, respectively, after the addition of CeO2. The selectivity rapidly decreased with the increasing of reaction temperature and dropped to 22%, 28%, 34% and 41% over the Cu/Al2O3, Cu/AlCeO-7, Cu/AlCeO-9 and Cu/AlCeO-5 at 553 K, respectively. In the previous reports, the methanol selectivity increased with the increasing amount of CO2 desorbed on the CuO-ZnO-ZrO2-SiO2 catalysts, indicating that the basic surface could promote the methanol production [38]. And on the Cu/ZrO2 catalysts with stronger basic sites, the space time yield of CO increased more slowly with the raise of reaction temperatures ranging from 493 to 553 K, which indicated that the strong basic sites could prevent CO production, especially at the high reaction temperatures [11]. Hence, the strong basic sites was more correlated with the active site for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation than that from weak and medium basic sites on the supported Cu catalysts, and the catalysts with more CeO2 had the more strong basic sites (Table 6). Theoretically, more basic sites and surface basicity on the catalyst could promote the chemisorption of CO2 [39], which may increase activation of CO2 hydrogenation. Meanwhile, CO was easily to be adsorbed on the basic surface due to its higher surface electron density [40–42], which inhibited the production of CO and subsequently improve the selectivity to methanol. In contrast, the basic surface could hinder the adsorption and dehydration of the alcohol [43], which could promote production of methanol. In addition, the XPS results showed that Cu-ceria interface increased with the addition of CeO2 due to the SMSI, which may increase the activity of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [12]. Hence, with the increasing of CeO2 addition, the Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5 exhibited monotonously methanol selectivity increase, which was higher than that on the Cu/ZnAlO and the results summed in Table 1. Calculation based on the data of CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity, the STYMeOH with the function of reaction temperature can be also obtained and the results were shown in Fig. 9C. It was seen that the STYMeOH firstly increased with reaction temperature until 493 K and then gradually decreased due to the increased CO production at the higher reaction temperature. The highest STYMeOH over Cu/Al2O3, Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5 value, were 3.3, 5.4, 7.2 and 6.2 mmol gcat. −1 h−1, respectively. It seen that the STYMeOH over Cu/ZnAlO was lower than that on the catalysts Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5 at the same reaction conditions. Due to the well mesoporous structure and appropriate SMSI, the Cu/AlCeO-7 catalyst has the high S Cu, strong basicity and more Cu-ceria interface, and thus exhibited the highest STYMeOH. The turnover frequency (TOF) represented the number of methanol-molecule production on unit site of exposed copper atom per second (s−1), which showed the catalytic efficiency of single Cu atom over the catalyst surface. In order to compare the catalytic efficiency of Cu/Al2O3, Cu/AlCeO-9, Cu/AlCeO-7, Cu/AlCeO-5 and Cu/ZnAlO, the TOFMeOH was calculated from the S Cu, which was shown in Fig. 9D. The results showed that the TOFMeOH for Cu/AlCeO-7 and Cu/AlCeO-5 was very close, which was higher than that for Cu/AlCeO-9, while the TOFMeOH for Cu/Al2O3 was the lower than that for Cu/AlCeO-9, which showed that the CeO2 increased TOFMeOH. It seemed that the surface basicity can increase the TOFMeOH. In addition, the TOFMeOH for Cu/AlCeO was much higher than that for Cu/ZnAlO catalysts, which indicated the mesostructured Cu/AlCeO catalysts would have the using prospect in industry. 4 Conclusions In summary, the mesostructured Cu/AlCeO catalysts have been successfully synthesized. The well mesostructure can obtain the high BET surface area and the interaction between the metal and supports could be controlled by the ratio of Al2O3 and CeO2, which promote the Cu dispersion, then the catalysts with high exposed Cu surface area were obtained. The Cu/AlCeO catalysts exhibited much improved catalytic performance in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol compared with the Cu/Al2O3. The CO2 conversion was closely related to the exposed Cu surface area (S Cu) and the methanol selectivity was closely related to the Cu-ceria interface and surface basicity. For the as-prepared catalyst, the Cu/AlCeO-7 with high S Cu, strong basicity and more Cu-ceria interface exhibited the most comprehensive performance for CO2 hydrogenation into methanol (V(H2)/V(CO2) = 3/1, GHSV = 6000 mL h−1 g−1 and P = 4 MPa). The CO2 conversion could be up to 22.5% at 553 K, the methanol selectivity could reach 94% at 473 K, and the STYMeOH was up to 7.2 mmol gcat. −1 h−1 at 493 K, which showed the mesostructured Cu/AlCeO-7 was an attractive catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. coredata.dc:description: Mesostructured catalysts with optimized microstructure and surface properties endowed them attractive catalytic performance. Herein, the mesostructured AlCeO supports with different weight ratio of Al2O3 and CeO2 have been prepared on the basis of a self-assembly sol-gel process, then 15 wt.% Cu was loaded onto the mesostructured AlCeO supports by incipient wetness impregnation method. The mesostructured AlCeO supports with varied ratio of Al2O3 to CeO2 resulted in the very different Cu particle size, and for the optimized catalyst Cu/AlCeO-7 (the amount of Al2O3 in AlCeO support was 70 wt.%), the Cu crystal size was around 7 nm based on the characterization of XRD and TEM. The Cu/AlCeO-7 catalyst had strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) and more Cu-ceria interface, which was confirmed by the XPS. Furthermore, the Cu/AlCeO-7 catalyst showed the highest exposed Cu surface area (S Cu) (25.5 m2/gcat) from the analysis results of H2-TPR and dissociative chemisorption of nitrous oxide. The CO2-TPD results demonstrated the Cu/AlCeO-7 had strong surface basicity. Hence, Cu/AlCeO-7 catalyst showed the highest space time yield of methanol (STYMeOH). The CO2 conversion (Cu/AlCeO-7, V(H2)/V(CO2) = 3/1, GHSV = 6000 mL h−1 g−1 and P = 4 MPa) was up to 22.5% at 553 K, the methanol selectivity can reach 94% at 473 K, and the STYMeOH was up to 7.2 mmol gcat. -1 h-1 at 493 K. The as-prepared mesostructured Cu/AlCeO-7 exhibited a promising catalyst candidate for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol.
coredata.dc:title: A highly active and selective mesostructured Cu/AlCeO catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol
